education.title: Breaking Free from Credit Card Debt
education.content1: Credit card debt can be one of the most expensive forms of borrowing, with average APRs around 20%. Making only minimum payments can take decades to pay off.
education.content2: The key to getting out of credit card debt is paying more than the minimum. Even small extra payments can save thousands in interest and years of payments.

tip1.title: Pay More Than Minimum
tip1.description: Minimum payments mostly cover interest, not principal.

tip2.title: Use the Avalanche Method
tip2.description: Pay highest interest debt first to save the most.

tip3.title: Consider Balance Transfer
tip3.description: 0% APR transfers can help if you pay off in time.

tip4.title: Stop Adding Debt
tip4.description: Cut up the card or freeze it while paying down.

faq.question: Why does minimum payment take so long?
faq.answer: Minimum payments are designed to maximize interest for the bank. Most of your payment goes to interest, barely touching the principal.

faq.question: Avalanche vs Snowball method?
faq.answer: Avalanche pays highest interest first (saves most money). Snowball pays smallest balance first (psychological wins). Avalanche is mathematically optimal.

faq.question: Should I use savings to pay off debt?
faq.answer: If your credit card APR is 20% and savings earn 2%, paying off debt is like earning 20% guaranteed. Keep a small emergency fund, then attack the debt.
